author: Alparslan Ozturk
title: Indian Raga Collection
description: A collection of traditional Hindustani classical ragas optimized for 16-step sequencing applications.
reference: Traditional Indian ragas with frequency calculations based on just intonation principles | A4=440Hz reference

collections.description: A selection of traditional ragas from the Hindustani classical music tradition of Northern India

modes.name: Bhimpalasi
modes.character: Romantic and introspective with afternoon serenity

steps.comment: komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave
komal Ga - Flat third degree 2 octaves
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Minor third, whole tone, whole tone, minor third, whole tone

metadata.description: Bhimpalasi is a melodious afternoon raga in Hindustani classical music that conveys a mood of introspection and romance. It has a distinctive pentatonic structure with the absence of Re (second) and Dha (sixth) degrees.
metadata.historicalContext: A popular raga in the Hindustani classical tradition, performed during the afternoon hours and frequently used in light classical forms
metadata.usageExamples: Afternoon concerts, light classical compositions like thumri and dadra, film music adaptations, fusion compositions

modes.name: Asavari
modes.character: Contemplative and serene with a sense of devotion

steps.comment: komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Whole tone, major third, whole tone, half tone, augmented fourth

metadata.description: Asavari is a pentatonic raga in Hindustani classical music that evokes a serene, contemplative mood. It is traditionally performed in the morning hours and is associated with devotional and introspective feelings.
metadata.historicalContext: One of the traditional ragas of North Indian classical music with ancient origins, mentioned in historical treatises on Indian music
metadata.usageExamples: Morning concerts, devotional compositions, meditative music, and alap (melodic improvisation) in Hindustani classical performances

modes.name: Bageshri
modes.character: Romantic and evocative with a sense of longing

steps.comment: komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave
komal Ga - Flat third degree 2 octaves
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Minor third, whole tone, augmented second, half tone, minor third

metadata.description: Bageshri is a popular late evening raga in Hindustani classical music that evokes romantic feelings and a sense of longing. It is especially effective in expressing the emotions of anticipation and yearning.
metadata.historicalContext: A raga with historical significance in Hindustani classical tradition, often featured in vocal compositions and instrumental performances
metadata.usageExamples: Late evening concerts, romantic compositions, khayal singing, instrumental alap exploration

modes.name: Bhairav
modes.character: Profound and meditative with a sense of divine awe

steps.comment: komal Re - Flat second degree octave
komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave
komal Re - Flat second degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Half tone, whole tone, augmented second, half tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone

metadata.description: Bhairav is one of the most ancient and revered ragas in Hindustani classical music, associated with Lord Shiva in his terrible form. It evokes a profound, meditative mood and is traditionally performed during the first quarter of the day (early morning).
metadata.historicalContext: One of the fundamental ragas in the Hindustani system, with origins dating back thousands of years in sacred music traditions
metadata.usageExamples: Dawn performances, spiritual and devotional music, serious classical recitals, extended alap sections

modes.name: Bhairavi
modes.character: Profound and devotional with melancholic undertones

steps.comment: komal Re - Flat second degree octave
komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave
komal Re - Flat second degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Half tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone

metadata.description: Bhairavi is one of the most important ragas in Hindustani classical music, often used to conclude concerts. It has a profound emotional quality, evoking feelings of devotion and peaceful melancholy.
metadata.historicalContext: Considered the 'queen of ragas' in the Hindustani tradition, with a history spanning centuries in Indian classical music
metadata.usageExamples: Traditional morning performances, concluding pieces in concerts, devotional music, thumri semi-classical compositions

modes.name: Bilawal
modes.character: Pure, bright and auspicious with morning freshness

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Whole tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone, whole tone, half tone

metadata.description: Bilawal is considered the most fundamental raga in North Indian classical music, equivalent to the Western major scale. It has a pure, bright quality and is traditionally performed in the morning hours.
metadata.historicalContext: Regarded as the fundamental 'shuddha' (pure) scale in Hindustani classical music, from which many other ragas are derived
metadata.usageExamples: Morning concerts, devotional compositions, auspicious occasions, teaching basic principles of Hindustani music

modes.name: Darbari Kanada
modes.character: Profound, serious and majestic with royal dignity

steps.comment: komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone

metadata.description: Darbari Kanada is one of the most majestic and profound ragas in Hindustani classical music, traditionally associated with royal courts. It has a serious, dignified character and is performed in the late evening hours.
metadata.historicalContext: Said to have been created or refined by Miyan Tansen for Emperor Akbar's court in the 16th century, representing the height of classical refinement
metadata.usageExamples: Late night concerts, serious classical recitals, extended alap sections, showcases of technical mastery in vocal and instrumental performance

modes.name: Hindol
modes.character: Bold and majestic with a sense of grandeur

steps.comment: tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Major third, whole tone, minor third, whole tone, whole tone

metadata.description: Hindol is a bold and majestic pentatonic raga in Hindustani classical music, associated with spring season (vasant). It has a distinctive structure that creates a sense of grandeur and color.
metadata.historicalContext: One of the ancient ragas in Indian classical music, traditionally associated with springtime and featured in paintings and poetry
metadata.usageExamples: Spring festival performances, morning concerts, evocative instrumental pieces, depictions of heroic or majestic themes

modes.name: Kafi
modes.character: Light, romantic and versatile with gentle contemplation

steps.comment: komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone

metadata.description: Kafi is a versatile and popular raga in Hindustani classical music with a gentle, contemplative character. It is the foundation for many folk songs and light classical compositions due to its adaptable melodic structure.
metadata.historicalContext: One of the ten fundamental 'thaat' scales in Hindustani music theory, with influences from folk music traditions
metadata.usageExamples: Semi-classical forms like thumri and dadra, bhajans (devotional songs), folk adaptations, evening performances

modes.name: Kedar
modes.character: Serene and devotional with calm dignity

steps.comment: tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Major third, whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone, whole tone, half tone

metadata.description: Kedar is a serene and devotional raga in Hindustani classical music with a distinctive phrasing that emphasizes the tivra Ma (augmented 4th). It has a dignified, contemplative character and is traditionally performed in the late evening.
metadata.historicalContext: Named after Lord Shiva (also known as Kedarnath), this raga has deep spiritual connotations in Indian classical tradition
metadata.usageExamples: Evening concerts, devotional compositions, meditative instrumental performances, spiritual gatherings

modes.name: Khamaj
modes.character: Playful and romantic with light expressiveness

steps.comment: komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Whole tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone

metadata.description: Khamaj is a bright and romantic raga in Hindustani classical music that evokes a playful, light mood. Its dominant 7th quality makes it popular for semi-classical and lighter forms of music.
metadata.historicalContext: One of the ten fundamental thaats (parent scales) in Hindustani music, with significant influence on popular and folk music forms
metadata.usageExamples: Light classical compositions, thumri, dadra, ghazal, bhajan, and evening concerts

modes.name: Lalit
modes.character: Profound and mystical with dawn serenity

steps.comment: komal Re - Flat second degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Re - Flat second degree 2 octaves
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Half tone, minor third, whole tone, whole tone, augmented second, half tone, half tone

metadata.description: Lalit is a mystical pre-dawn raga in Hindustani classical music with a distinctive combination of minor and major intervals. Its unusual structure creates a meditative atmosphere associated with the twilight hours before sunrise.
metadata.historicalContext: A specialized raga traditionally performed in the early morning hours before sunrise (4-6 AM), considered auspicious for spiritual practice
metadata.usageExamples: Pre-dawn concerts, devotional music, meditative instrumentals, spiritual gatherings at dawn

modes.name: Malkauns
modes.character: Profound and intense with a mystical quality

steps.comment: komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave
komal Ga - Flat third degree 2 octaves
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree 2 octaves
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Minor third, whole tone, minor third, whole tone, minor third

metadata.description: Malkauns is one of the most profound pentatonic ragas in Hindustani classical music, characterized by its intense, serious mood. All non-tonic notes are flattened, creating a distinctive dark quality and meditative atmosphere.
metadata.historicalContext: An ancient raga with mythological associations to Lord Shiva and the ability to create supernatural effects when properly performed
metadata.usageExamples: Late night concerts, extended alap (improvisation), serious classical performances, spiritual contexts

modes.name: Marwa
modes.character: Serious and profound with sunset solemnity

steps.comment: komal Re - Flat second degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
komal Re - Flat second degree 2 octaves
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Half tone, major third, whole tone, minor third, whole tone, half tone

metadata.description: Marwa is a profound and austere raga in Hindustani classical music that omits the perfect fifth (Pa) and creates a distinctive tension through its augmented fourth. Traditionally performed during sunset, it evokes a serious, contemplative mood.
metadata.historicalContext: An ancient raga considered difficult to master, with historical significance in the court traditions of North Indian classical music
metadata.usageExamples: Sunset performances, serious classical concerts, extended alap sections, advanced demonstration pieces

modes.name: Miyan Ki Malhar
modes.character: Expansive and majestic with monsoon imagery

steps.comment: komal Ni - Flat seventh degree octave
komal Ni - Flat seventh degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Whole tone, minor third, whole tone, minor third, whole tone

metadata.description: Miyan Ki Malhar is a celebrated monsoon raga in Hindustani classical music, renowned for its ability to evoke the mood of the rainy season. It has a distinctive structure that creates the atmosphere of clouds gathering and rainfall.
metadata.historicalContext: Attributed to Miyan Tansen, the legendary musician in Emperor Akbar's court (16th century), with many stories of its magical power to bring rainfall
metadata.usageExamples: Monsoon season concerts, evocative nature portrayals, classical vocal performances with complex ornamentations

modes.name: Purvi
modes.character: Serious and contemplative with evening serenity

steps.comment: komal Re - Flat second degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Re - Flat second degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Half tone, augmented second, whole tone, half tone, half tone, augmented second, half tone

metadata.description: Purvi is a profound evening raga in Hindustani classical music with a complex structure that includes both the augmented fourth and major seventh. It creates a serious, contemplative atmosphere ideal for the early evening hours.
metadata.historicalContext: One of the important ragas in the Purvi thaat family, traditionally performed during the early evening transitional hours
metadata.usageExamples: Early evening concerts, serious classical recitals, extended instrumental explorations, spiritual gatherings

modes.name: Shri
modes.character: Serene and majestic with dignified expressiveness

steps.comment: komal Re - Flat second degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Re - Flat second degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Half tone, major third, whole tone, half tone, half tone, augmented second, half tone

metadata.description: Shri is a dignified and serene raga in Hindustani classical music that creates a majestic, expansive atmosphere. Its distinctive slow phrases and carefully articulated notes evoke a feeling of reverence and grandeur.
metadata.historicalContext: Named after the honorific 'Shri' (indicating respect), this raga has ancient origins and is associated with auspicious occasions and divine qualities
metadata.usageExamples: Afternoon concerts, serious classical performances, devotional contexts, auspicious ceremonial occasions

modes.name: Sohini
modes.character: Vibrant and bright with pre-dawn expectancy

steps.comment: tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Major third, whole tone, minor third, whole tone, whole tone

metadata.description: Sohini is a vibrant and bright pentatonic raga in Hindustani classical music traditionally performed in the pre-dawn hours. It has a distinctive uplifting character with a bright, expectant quality.
metadata.historicalContext: Associated with the early morning hours before sunrise, often paired with other morning ragas in traditional performances
metadata.usageExamples: Pre-dawn concerts, end-of-night performances, spiritual gatherings at daybreak, morning invocations

modes.name: Todi
modes.character: Profound and meditative with serious intensity

steps.comment: komal Re - Flat second degree octave
komal Ga - Flat third degree octave
tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave
komal Dha - Flat sixth degree octave
komal Re - Flat second degree 2 octaves

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Half tone, whole tone, augmented second, half tone, half tone, augmented second, half tone

metadata.description: Todi is considered one of the most complex and profound ragas in Hindustani classical music. Its unique combination of flattened and augmented notes creates a deeply meditative, serious atmosphere that requires intense concentration.
metadata.historicalContext: One of the oldest and most revered ragas, with complex rules for performance and a distinguished position in morning concerts
metadata.usageExamples: Late morning concerts, serious classical recitals, meditative performances, demonstrations of musical mastery

modes.name: Yaman
modes.character: Serene and peaceful with evening tranquility

steps.comment: tivra Ma - Sharp fourth degree octave

microtonalCharacteristics.tuningSystem: Just intonation approximated in equal temperament
microtonalCharacteristics.intervalStructure: Whole tone, whole tone, whole tone, half tone, whole tone, whole tone, half tone

metadata.description: Yaman (also known as Kalyan) is one of the most important and fundamental ragas in Hindustani classical music. Its tranquil, serene character makes it ideal for evening performances, and it is often one of the first ragas taught to students.
metadata.historicalContext: One of the principal ragas of the Kalyan thaat, traditionally performed during the early evening hours at sunset
metadata.usageExamples: Evening concerts, teaching basic principles of Hindustani music, devotional music, serene instrumental performances

performance_practices.microtonal_inflections: Indian ragas use subtle microtonal inflections called 'shrutis' that aren't captured in equal temperament. These intervals create the distinctive emotional resonance of each raga.
performance_practices.rhythmic_features: Raga performances typically progress through structured rhythmic cycles called 'talas' which vary in length and complexity, creating distinctive rhythmic frameworks.
performance_practices.ornamentation: Traditional performance includes various ornamentations such as meend (glides), kan (grace notes), andolan (oscillations), and gamak (heavy oscillations) that are essential to the raga's character.
performance_practices.instrumentation: Traditionally performed on instruments like sitar, sarod, santoor, bansuri (flute), and tabla, with vocal performances being highly regarded in the classical tradition.
